positive.review: Idle games are a dime a dozen. But this game has a depth to it that engages you better than most. Add on top of that, the game meta changes drastically a key points, essentially making it a whole new game regularly. Definitely worth it for people who like idle games and min/maxing at the same time!

TL;DR: Interesting idle game concept but likely less enjoyable without a guide if you want to progress further without missing stuff.

It's an idle game that certainly has some depth considering what I've been seeing on the internet.
That itself is also the reason why the game felt kind of odd when I first started it. While managing to unlock more upgrades and working on trophies, some things just feel hidden and not highlighted as important when you actually need them.

The gameplay focusses more on swapping your choice of upgrades, every time you restart a run to be more efficient in your global gameplay.
And here lies the biggest problem. Without a guide you will start to question why progress might hit a big bump, likely because u missed something. 
That's the reason I'm using a guide which shows me important things for my current progress and tells me about things I could do, might do but not need to or shouldn't do yet. It gives a better feeling of knowing that you will make progress and not constantly bump your head on a wall.
Very interresting and fun idle game.
simple and complicated, so fun
Deep and quite addictive, lots of upgrades and strategy
A highly-regarded incremental game where you start as a humble realm owner and grow your kingdom through strategic choices, faction alliances, and complex upgrades.
cool idle game, but need more detail about the how to

A classic browser idler brought to steam!

Very fucking addicting

yummy
I would say its decent. One of the better clicker games for sure.

A rare example of a game that starts out simple, but builds complexity depending on how quickly you can master the earlier mechanics, creating a satisfying experience throughout - as long as you're able to find an efficient path forward. There are points at which you fly through the progression, and times where things slow down and really push you to find the most optimal path forward. The game rewards both active and idle gameplay depending on your chosen factions (which can be swapped easily), with some upgrades only being accessible by spending time offline; but the overall trend is towards automation the deeper you go, as with most good incremental games.

My only real complaint is that the secret in-game achievements are all tied to upgrades, so you're strongly incentivized to look up the requirements online for any which you don't unlock accidentally or figure out yourself; these were fun for community-building when this game first launched on a site for flash games which had forums and chat functions, but with all of them solved it just creates a progression difference between those who look them up and those who insist on not spoiling anything and trying to figure everything out on their own. But that's ultimately a minor gripe which can be resolved in a few seconds via search engine.

Overall, if you want an incremental game that rewards analytical skills and experimenting with builds, with a very long road to completion, this is a great choice. I can't comment on the late game portions yet as I haven't reached them, but I find what's here to be very satisfying. All these years later, and it's still getting content updates!
Over the years my interests in this kind of games waned. But I can't deny that this idler boasts the unexpected depth and complexity not usually present in such titles.

Idle games are a dime a dozen. But this game has a depth to it that engages you better than most. Add on top of that, the game meta changes drastically a key points, essentially making it a whole new game regularly. Definitely worth it for people who like idle games and min/maxing at the same time!

TL;DR: Interesting idle game concept but likely less enjoyable without a guide if you want to progress further without missing stuff.

It's an idle game that certainly has some depth considering what I've been seeing on the internet.
That itself is also the reason why the game felt kind of odd when I first started it. While managing to unlock more upgrades and working on trophies, some things just feel hidden and not highlighted as important when you actually need them.

The gameplay focusses more on swapping your choice of upgrades, every time you restart a run to be more efficient in your global gameplay.
And here lies the biggest problem. Without a guide you will start to question why progress might hit a big bump, likely because u missed something. 
That's the reason I'm using a guide which shows me important things for my current progress and tells me about things I could do, might do but not need to or shouldn't do yet. It gives a better feeling of knowing that you will make progress and not constantly bump your head on a wall.
Best and most complex idler there is and the devs keep updating it for decades.
Very interresting and fun idle game.
simple and complicated, so fun
Interesting. Would be interesting to add some sort of passive fighting dungeon or something similar.

Addictive and surprisingly deep for a free incremental game! I've spent hours optimizing my kingdom and unlocking new content. Progress feels rewarding, and there's always another goal to strive for. Definitely worth checking out if you enjoy watching numbers go up.
Deep and quite addictive, lots of upgrades and strategy

Игра Realm Grinder - это увлекательный представитель жанра idle, где ты начинаешь с малого и постепенно строишь огромную империю, экспериментируя с различными фракциями, улучшениями и перерождениями. Геймплей построен вокруг бесконечного цикла накопления ресурсов и открытия новых возможностей. Сначала все кажется простым, но потом раскрывается сложная система престижа, с множеством путей развития и необходимостью оптимизировать свои стратегии.

Мне понравилось разнообразие доступных фракций, каждая из которых предлагает уникальные бонусы и стили игры. Процесс поиска оптимальной комбинации для максимальной эффективности очень увлекателен. Графика, конечно, простенькая, но это не сильно портит впечатления, учитывая глубину геймплея.

Пожалуй, единственный минус - это некоторое однообразие в поздней игре, когда уже опробованы многие стратегии, и остается только методичное увеличение чисел. Однако, постоянные обновления и добавление нового контента частично решают эту проблему. В целом, Realm Grinder - отличный выбор для любителей idle-игр, желающих погрузиться в сложный и захватывающий мир.

This is a really fun little idle, but not a real idle, game. If you have an auto clicker (like OP Auto Clicker), you can upgrade a lot of buildings a lot quicker. There are a lot of different ways to level up as well, including various factions you can join. Still need to get that last achievement though!

It's a free idle game, not really much bad to say about it.

If you don't like it, who cares, it was free dude.

It's a clicker game. You grind the realm. What is there more to say?

Why are you even reading the review of a clicker game?
probably my favorite incremental that stays under the infinity range

negative.review:
lmao - wow!

At first, I was a fan. Seemed grounded enough and a package for a fiver to support the devs felt fair.

As of today, we have reached "Give us ten bucks so you can get bonusses when logging in every day" - so... paying for dailies. There's a premium currency but it's "toootally not pay2win or anything" - it's just that, of course, everything becomes painfully slow down the line. I even considered getting some bc the gameplay was kinda nice, but the prices are ridiculous.

I would've fully understood the entire business setup if the prices weren't so !!outrageously!! high. But these devs clearly have some dollar signs in their eyes. I might even keep playing as a non-paying customer just because every now and again it's alright to unwind - but having people pay for !!dailies!! deserves the shame of a bad review!!

the game was good untill you are forced to use in-game shop. and the predatory shop is insane. you have one option to buy a small general boost and only after you buy that one the gem "unlocks" you the "secret" option to buy another much stronger boost for double the price. And from my understanding, there are several layers witch increasing prices.
Does not work on Silicon based Macs, all previous gameplay and progress is now inaccessible.

Good game, but shit achievement method to get players to either buy in-game currency or waste their lives.

Time needed to get achievements 1-13, about 20 hours

Time needed to get achievement 14, over 2000 hours.

Not wasting my life for one achievement, the game is boring as shit anyways after the first reincarnation.

I play alot of different games and even idle games. But this one does not offer alot options just one linear path.  graphics are ok but not enough to keep my attention. I did give it a full hour before deciding i was bored.

[h1][b] TLDR: Very average and very repetitive. [/b] [/h1]

[h1]PROS: [/h1]
➕Different playstyles through racial bonuses


[h1]CONS: [/h1]
➖No way to increase UI size(?)
➖Pay to progress much faster
➖Repetitive 
➖No audio slider, just on or off

[h1] [b] Content (Game world/Narrative) – [4/10] [/b] [/h1]
The game world consists entirely of a single screen with an area of land that various buildings are built upon. The only thing that changes within my playtime was the color palette. 

There isn’t really a narrative. 

[h1][b] Gameplay (Mechanics/Difficulty) – [6/10] [/b] [/h1]
As far as the mechanics go, this feels like a fairly traditional idle progression game to me. The bulk of the gameplay consists of simply reincarnating over and over to accumulate larger numbers. 
By far the largest original mechanic this game has is the racial decision and bonuses. The ise a choice between good and evil (at the start) each with 3 choices. Each race has their own strengths that benefit different playstyles. For example, the elves are focused on clicking, while the fairies give big bonuses to your starting buildings. There are even additional factions and races to unlock that generally focus on different aspects of the game, but the core always remains the same - reincarnate. 

While the game isn’t necessarily difficult, there is a large lack of direction. For the first dozen or so hours, I had no idea what I should be doing. Furthermore, googling isn’t helpful since apparently there was such large patches to the game that all information aside from whats on Discord seems to be outdated. There is a small hint section that provides help, but it took me hours to actually accidentally stumble across it (its in the very bottom right….). 

[h1] [b] Graphics (Quality/Technical) – [4/10] [/b] [/h1]
Absolutely nothing special. From a graphical standpoint, this is Playstation 1-era fidelity. 
I don’t mind poor graphics, but the thing that kills me is the inability to increase UI size. Such a basic thing that makes the game that much harder to enjoy. 

On the technical side, I encountered no bugs or issues with running it. 
i9-13900KF | RTX 4090 | 64GB RAM | 1440p @ 240hz | Windows 11 installed on SSD 

[h1] [b] Audio – [2/10] [/b] [/h1]
Audio is largely repetitive. There is only 3 (that I found) different soundtracks, one for each faction. Either way, I ended up muting the sound because there was no volume slider. I’d have preferred it quieter, but its either on or off. 

[h1] [b] Replay Factor (Longevity) – [7/10] [/b] [/h1]
There is some great replay value here, if you have the patience and can endure the repetitive playstyle. The game slowly drip feeds you new mechanics as you progress, but this often can take dozens of hours. Still, to see everything the game has to offer, it can be a massive time commitment. 

[h1] [b] Final Verdict – [5/10] [/b] [/h1]
Realm Grinder (RG) caught my attention as one of the higher scored idle games on Steam. Being that it was free, I decided to try it out over the course of a week or two. 
There were two things that become evident to me immediately within the first few hours of playtime - the repetition and the lack of direction. The repetition is fairly standard for an idle game, which consists mostly of restarting over and over for bigger numbers, but I thought it was fairly egregious in RG. You are expected to restart within the first few hours to take advantage of different races while collecting in-game trophies. That’s 6 restarts right there. And while the races do offer different bonuses and benefits, they do not change the gameplay nearly enough to warrant restarting so much. 
As for the lack of direction, I had no idea what I should be doing at the beginning, so I just kind of winged it. The game hides a tiny little advisor in the bottom right that gives you a single sentence on what you should be focusing on. 

In my ~35 hours of playtime, I did not find RG deep or unique enough to continue. Furthermore, despite it being free to play, there is a cash shop that sells you a currency that very clearly will expedite your experience. So while it's a single player game, the pay-to-win option is present. 
I think if RG wanted to grab my attention, I would have loved to actually see small previews of the games supposedly “Deep” systems instead of everything supposedly cool being hidden behind dozens of hours of repetition. 
Due to the above, I cannot recommend this game. My recommendation for an idle game is Melvor Idle, [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Synikx/recommended/1267910?snr=1_5_9__402]you can read my review here[/url]. 

[h1] [b] Recommend? (Price) [Y/N] [/b] [/h1]
[h1]No[/h1]
Could be worth a shot since it's free, but just be mindful of P2W issues. 
You can find my curator page here: https://steamcommunity.com/groups/Synik_GR
Steam keeps pestering me to leave a review, so here's a negative one. I'll be leaving the same rating for every game steam pesters me to review.
cant scry on my platform unless i buy it permanently? enjoy the downvote
Lil' Potato, Hot as f$%k. Lil' Potato, Bust a nut.
Horrible. Locked behind paywall. AVOID.

It's pretty neat to start with, but I got all but one achievement 150 hours ago, and it looks like it'll be at least long until I get the last, so eh.
I like the kongregate idle games because they tend to be finishable, this one is not.
anti autoclicker, heavy incentives on buying rubys for short progression and "skipping", decent depth

Idle clicker games are, by their very nature, the gaming equivalent of that annoying person who constantly taps their fingers on whatever surface they are near. Calling them “games” is probably breaking the definition of the word, and Realm Grinder is a master of futility. Click the button and you can build more things, except you don’t. Own thousands of farms? Maybe, but you’ll just see one, same as with everything else. There is the minimum amount possible in the way of visual reward to be gained, and even less in the way of enjoyment. It’s soulless, purposeless, and a waste of time. A better option would be to put your mouse in your pocket and go for a walk. That way, you’ll still be accompanied by the endless sound of clickety-clack, and you’ll at least have something to look at.
Steam keeps pestering me to leave a review, so here's a negative one. I'll be leaving the same rating for every game steam pesters me to review.
The game looks fun but doesn't run on my Macbook air M4... Truly a shame
cant scry on my platform unless i buy it permanently? enjoy the downvote
It gets boring quickly.
Lil' Potato, Hot as f$%k. Lil' Potato, Bust a nut.
Horrible. Locked behind paywall. AVOID.
As boring as it gets.

lmao - wow!

At first, I was a fan. Seemed grounded enough and a package for a fiver to support the devs felt fair.

As of today, we have reached "Give us ten bucks so you can get bonusses when logging in every day" - so... paying for dailies. There's a premium currency but it's "toootally not pay2win or anything" - it's just that, of course, everything becomes painfully slow down the line. I even considered getting some bc the gameplay was kinda nice, but the prices are ridiculous.

I would've fully understood the entire business setup if the prices weren't so !!outrageously!! high. But these devs clearly have some dollar signs in their eyes. I might even keep playing as a non-paying customer just because every now and again it's alright to unwind - but having people pay for !!dailies!! deserves the shame of a bad review!!

the game was good untill you are forced to use in-game shop. and the predatory shop is insane. you have one option to buy a small general boost and only after you buy that one the gem "unlocks" you the "secret" option to buy another much stronger boost for double the price. And from my understanding, there are several layers witch increasing prices.
Does not work on Silicon based Macs, all previous gameplay and progress is now inaccessible.
this game was a good game, but after so many hours, I have to say it’s not good because this game has A LOT of things to buy and that makes me sad because I loved this game, but not anymore

Good game, but shit achievement method to get players to either buy in-game currency or waste their lives.

Time needed to get achievements 1-13, about 20 hours

Time needed to get achievement 14, over 2000 hours.

Not wasting my life for one achievement, the game is boring as shit anyways after the first reincarnation.

I play alot of different games and even idle games. But this one does not offer alot options just one linear path.  graphics are ok but not enough to keep my attention. I did give it a full hour before deciding i was bored.

[h1][b] TLDR: Very average and very repetitive. [/b] [/h1]

[h1]PROS: [/h1]
➕Different playstyles through racial bonuses


[h1]CONS: [/h1]
➖No way to increase UI size(?)
➖Pay to progress much faster
➖Repetitive 
➖No audio slider, just on or off

[h1] [b] Content (Game world/Narrative) – [4/10] [/b] [/h1]
The game world consists entirely of a single screen with an area of land that various buildings are built upon. The only thing that changes within my playtime was the color palette. 

There isn’t really a narrative. 

[h1][b] Gameplay (Mechanics/Difficulty) – [6/10] [/b] [/h1]
As far as the mechanics go, this feels like a fairly traditional idle progression game to me. The bulk of the gameplay consists of simply reincarnating over and over to accumulate larger numbers. 
By far the largest original mechanic this game has is the racial decision and bonuses. The ise a choice between good and evil (at the start) each with 3 choices. Each race has their own strengths that benefit different playstyles. For example, the elves are focused on clicking, while the fairies give big bonuses to your starting buildings. There are even additional factions and races to unlock that generally focus on different aspects of the game, but the core always remains the same - reincarnate. 

While the game isn’t necessarily difficult, there is a large lack of direction. For the first dozen or so hours, I had no idea what I should be doing. Furthermore, googling isn’t helpful since apparently there was such large patches to the game that all information aside from whats on Discord seems to be outdated. There is a small hint section that provides help, but it took me hours to actually accidentally stumble across it (its in the very bottom right….). 

[h1] [b] Graphics (Quality/Technical) – [4/10] [/b] [/h1]
Absolutely nothing special. From a graphical standpoint, this is Playstation 1-era fidelity. 
I don’t mind poor graphics, but the thing that kills me is the inability to increase UI size. Such a basic thing that makes the game that much harder to enjoy. 

On the technical side, I encountered no bugs or issues with running it. 
i9-13900KF | RTX 4090 | 64GB RAM | 1440p @ 240hz | Windows 11 installed on SSD 

[h1] [b] Audio – [2/10] [/b] [/h1]
Audio is largely repetitive. There is only 3 (that I found) different soundtracks, one for each faction. Either way, I ended up muting the sound because there was no volume slider. I’d have preferred it quieter, but its either on or off. 

[h1] [b] Replay Factor (Longevity) – [7/10] [/b] [/h1]
There is some great replay value here, if you have the patience and can endure the repetitive playstyle. The game slowly drip feeds you new mechanics as you progress, but this often can take dozens of hours. Still, to see everything the game has to offer, it can be a massive time commitment. 

[h1] [b] Final Verdict – [5/10] [/b] [/h1]
Realm Grinder (RG) caught my attention as one of the higher scored idle games on Steam. Being that it was free, I decided to try it out over the course of a week or two. 
There were two things that become evident to me immediately within the first few hours of playtime - the repetition and the lack of direction. The repetition is fairly standard for an idle game, which consists mostly of restarting over and over for bigger numbers, but I thought it was fairly egregious in RG. You are expected to restart within the first few hours to take advantage of different races while collecting in-game trophies. That’s 6 restarts right there. And while the races do offer different bonuses and benefits, they do not change the gameplay nearly enough to warrant restarting so much. 
As for the lack of direction, I had no idea what I should be doing at the beginning, so I just kind of winged it. The game hides a tiny little advisor in the bottom right that gives you a single sentence on what you should be focusing on. 

In my ~35 hours of playtime, I did not find RG deep or unique enough to continue. Furthermore, despite it being free to play, there is a cash shop that sells you a currency that very clearly will expedite your experience. So while it's a single player game, the pay-to-win option is present. 
I think if RG wanted to grab my attention, I would have loved to actually see small previews of the games supposedly “Deep” systems instead of everything supposedly cool being hidden behind dozens of hours of repetition. 
Due to the above, I cannot recommend this game. My recommendation for an idle game is Melvor Idle, [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Synikx/recommended/1267910?snr=1_5_9__402]you can read my review here[/url]. 

[h1] [b] Recommend? (Price) [Y/N] [/b] [/h1]
[h1]No[/h1]
Could be worth a shot since it's free, but just be mindful of P2W issues. 
You can find my curator page here: https://steamcommunity.com/groups/Synik_GR

[h1] [b] Graphics (Quality/Technical) – [4/10] [/b] [/h1]
Absolutely nothing special. From a graphical standpoint, this is Playstation 1-era fidelity. 
I don’t mind poor graphics, but the thing that kills me is the inability to increase UI size. Such a basic thing that makes the game that much harder to enjoy. 

On the technical side, I encountered no bugs or issues with running it. 
i9-13900KF | RTX 4090 | 64GB RAM | 1440p @ 240hz | Windows 11 installed on SSD 

[h1] [b] Audio – [2/10] [/b] [/h1]
Audio is largely repetitive. There is only 3 (that I found) different soundtracks, one for each faction. Either way, I ended up muting the sound because there was no volume slider. I’d have preferred it quieter, but its either on or off. 

[h1] [b] Replay Factor (Longevity) – [7/10] [/b] [/h1]
There is some great replay value here, if you have the patience and can endure the repetitive playstyle. The game slowly drip feeds you new mechanics as you progress, but this often can take dozens of hours. Still, to see everything the game has to offer, it can be a massive time commitment. 

[h1] [b] Final Verdict – [5/10] [/b] [/h1]
Realm Grinder (RG) caught my attention as one of the higher scored idle games on Steam. Being that it was free, I decided to try it out over the course of a week or two. 
There were two things that become evident to me immediately within the first few hours of playtime - the repetition and the lack of direction. The repetition is fairly standard for an idle game, which consists mostly of restarting over and over for bigger numbers, but I thought it was fairly egregious in RG. You are expected to restart within the first few hours to take advantage of different races while collecting in-game trophies. That’s 6 restarts right there. And while the races do offer different bonuses and benefits, they do not change the gameplay nearly enough to warrant restarting so much. 
As for the lack of direction, I had no idea what I should be doing at the beginning, so I just kind of winged it. The game hides a tiny little advisor in the bottom right that gives you a single sentence on what you should be focusing on. 

In my ~35 hours of playtime, I did not find RG deep or unique enough to continue. Furthermore, despite it being free to play, there is a cash shop that sells you a currency that very clearly will expedite your experience. So while it's a single player game, the pay-to-win option is present. 
I think if RG wanted to grab my attention, I would have loved to actually see small previews of the games supposedly “Deep” systems instead of everything supposedly cool being hidden behind dozens of hours of repetition. 
Due to the above, I cannot recommend this game. My recommendation for an idle game is Melvor Idle, [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Synikx/recommended/1267910?snr=1_5_9__402]you can read my review here[/url]. 

[h1] [b] Recommend? (Price) [Y/N] [/b] [/h1]
[h1]No[/h1]
Could be worth a shot since it's free, but just be mindful of P2W issues. 
You can find my curator page here: https://steamcommunity.com/groups/Synik_GR

anti autoclicker, heavy incentives on buying rubys for short progression and "skipping", decent depth

Idle clicker games are, by their very nature, the gaming equivalent of that annoying person who constantly taps their fingers on whatever surface they are near. Calling them “games” is probably breaking the definition of the word, and Realm Grinder is a master of futility. Click the button and you can build more things, except you don’t. Own thousands of farms? Maybe, but you’ll just see one, same as with everything else. There is the minimum amount possible in the way of visual reward to be gained, and even less in the way of enjoyment. It’s soulless, purposeless, and a waste of time. A better option would be to put your mouse in your pocket and go for a walk. That way, you’ll still be accompanied by the endless sound of clickety-clack, and you’ll at least have something to look at.
